fol.18r
Maye it please yo
r
good L. to be advertised, that when I came to the
Hage,
e 27 of the laste, I founde the moste of the
States
awaye,
beying all invited by the
Co. of Hohenlo
, to be at his mariage, with
the
Countesse of Buren
, which was solemnised at
Buren,
a litle
towne with a Castel appertening to
e Countesse, between
Culenbourgh
and
Tiel.
I doo finde in lyke maner
at
e
Provinces
have not yeelded as yet to
e
Councels
proposition, for the extraordi-
narie contribution of this yeere, for which they have demaunded
eight score thousand poundes sterling: which is seventie thousand
more then was ever yet requyred,
e laste yeere excepted. Howe it
will be obtained it is very uncertaine: but yet all men are in hope,
that it will be raised in the ende: albeit I am tould that my coming
heere to soone, will rather hurt then helpe it forwarde. For I
doe serve my selfe of dyvers reasons to drawe them on the paye
their debtes, of which some will take hold to excuse their con-
tributing:
at if their grant had bin past before I had come
hither, it had bin undoubtedly a farre fitter opportunitie.
Yesterday morning I had my audience of the States, of whome
I was heard in a full assemblie: but I had no other aunswear
then they are wont to deliver in all suche affaires, That they
will take some tyme to thinke upon it, requyring to have my
proposition in wryting, whereof heereinclosed I send the Copie to
your L: I will hasten their aunswear as much as I maye,
and sollicit them the whyle to give her
Ma
tie
content. First by
some good portion of mony in hande: secondly by some annuall
payment till all be discharged: and lastly by abating a parte
of her present expences. they are very muche troubled
with this matter, and waxe so silent upon it, as I can not
yet imagine what successe I shall have: but I am in good
hope to learne out somwhat of their purpose; and to write it
in my next. This day I am to deale with the Councel of
Estate, to whome I will deliver her Ma
ties
l
re
and participat
as muche as I proposed to
e States: But
Co. Maurice
is
in
Gelderland,
with whome I muste deale altogether by l
re
s,
if I see any likelihood that he will stay in those quarters.
fol.18v
Coronel Stuart
is come hither from the
Scottishe Kinge
, and hath
delivered his messsage: wherof all
at I can learne, is that hee
seeketh to renue the ancient amities and alliances between the
two contries: and with all is a suitor to be assisted against his
rebels at home: whether the K
s
desire be for money or men,
I shall not be able to signifie directly, till I have spoken with
the coronel himself, or with some of the States, which I purpose
with the soonest and will advertise accordingly.
The reporte
at hath gone of
e Germane Ambassadors,
at should
come to treat of peace, is still a foote in these Contreis. It is
determined, they say,
at of 12 speciall persons deputed therunto,
there shall sixe repayre to
Brussels,
and sixe to this place, to
witte, twoo from
e Ecclesiasticall State, two from
e Princes,
and other twoe from the Townes: and that certaine Heraldes
wearing their coates shall be sent before, to declare to
e people
in places where they passe, the ocasion of their coming. But
I can not yet perceave,
at they have yet resolved heere, what
course they will take for admitting or stopping their comming
though I see no inclination
at they will enter into Treatie.
Heere hath gone a speeche of late of 3 townes taken by
e
D. of
Bouillon
in
e land of
Luxembourgh
Juois, La Frotte, and [Cheval]
w
ch
lye upon a branche of the Mose: with all, it is said,
at he hath
defeated 11 Cornets of
e Ennemies horse: but though the newes
come hither about 6 dayes sins, it is no further yet confirmed.
About the same time we were also advertised,
at
e Castle of
Huy
a strong place in
e land of
Liege,
lieng upon the Mose,
neere to
e Citie of Liege, is surprised by certaine souldiers of the
States, which were presently seconded by dyvers other troupes: but
howe they will speede, it is doubted very much, because the contrey
there is populous, and full of gentlemen, which are very well pro-
vided of warlicke furniture. But if they chaunce to hold the place
considering that the D. of Bouillon is there at hand, with his
armie, which are said together with the States forces to be 9000
foote, and 1500 horse, it will proove a very speciall annoyance to
the Ennemies actions. It is held for certaine heere,
at
fol.19r
the Italians mutined have accorded with
Ernestus,
for which
many men blame the states of these Contreis,
at they cutte them
not in peeces when it was in their power. It is written from
Andwerpe,
at
Richardot,
Assonville, and Vasseur, principall
persons of
e Spanish Councell at Brussels, are displaced by
the
King:
but there are that doubt
e certaintie.
They are greatly grieved heere,
at they can not stand assured
of these English troupes, which they entertaine, being hindred by
it in making their designes, for not knowing what forces
they may imploy in any enterprise. At my being in
Middlebourgh
I receaved a l
re
from
S
r
Robert Cecill
, with a second
discourse of the Scottish affaires, wherof in as much as no
other matter is yet offred unto me, to write to his Hono
r
,
I humblie beseech you to give him some intelligence.
And so I take my humble leave./ From the Hage Fe
b
5.
Heere is brute at this very instant, that both the Castle and towne
of Huy, are in our possession: but withall it is said
at of the nom-
bers of our horse, which went to succor these places, as neede should
requyre, being 7 or 8 Companies returning homeward, with their
praye, which they say was very great, 3 or 4 Cornets in
e advant-
garde were cleane defeated, by an Embuscado of
e Enemie, and
the rest put to flight. Howe true it is I can not signifie, but
it carieth a great likelihood, and it is reported very constantly./
